Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Risk perception and health-related knowledge and practice

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Humanitarian responders have a high risk of contracting travel-related illnesses which can be carried back to the US and pose a threat to the health of the population. Knowledge, attitudes and practices (KAP) are important factors relating to risk of travel-related illness, yet little is known about how risk perception impacts behavior among humanitarian responders. The research team developed a conceptual framework that integrates the Tripartite Model of Risk Perception (TRIRISK) Model into a KAP framework to assess whether KAPs on travel-related health risks influence TRIRISK perceptions and whether those perceptions, in turn, influence protective health behaviors and ultimately health outcomes. Research using this model has focused on behavioral intentions as the outcome. This study extends the TRIRISK Model by validating its use in acute diseases and provides the first look at the role knowledge has in forming TRIRISK perceptions and the association between the TRIRISK perceptions and health behaviors. This research improves our understanding of how knowledge and risk perception impact the decisions, behaviors and health outcomes for humanitarian workers responding to disasters and enables the development of more targeted and effective guidance materials for agencies and healthcare providers to share with travelers.

The overall goal of this research project is to identify the knowledge and risk perception of humanitarian aid workers in relation to the health behaviors they engage in during a deployment to a foreign disaster zone and how those behaviors relate to their risk of becoming ill. This project adapts the Tripartite Model of Risk Perception (TRIRISK) by including knowledge, attitudes, and practices to it and exploring both health behaviors and health outcomes. The research uses a purposive sample of 100 humanitarian aid workers who are responding to the two tropical cyclones. These humanitarian aid workers are from US government agencies (primarily USAID), UN and WHO agencies, and non-governmental organizations. The research team administers a questionnaire assessing Knowledge, Attitudes, and Practices related to protecting their health while traveling, as well as assessing risk perceptions in relation to travel-related illness. Additionally, the participants maintain a daily log of their eating, drinking, and hygiene behaviors as well as any illness episodes during their deployment. Multi-variate modeling of the data follows the adapted theoretical model analyzing the impact of KAP and risk perception on health behaviors and ultimately health outcomes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over life of the award for this Rapid Response Research Program (RAPID) Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant (DDRIG), which started August 15,2019 and ended July 31, 2020, resulted in provided essential support for key activities associated with engaging in time-sensitive and often difficult-to-study research during an active international disaster response & recovery. The primary direct activities directly supported by this award were to provide international travel from the U.S. to Mozambique to carry out in-person interviews/facilitated survey data collection among international humanitarian response agency personnel involved with response and recovery programmatic activities related to Tropical Cyclone Idai which hit the central coast of Mozambique causing widespread population health impacts. In addition to direct travel costs, support also covered key supplies and materials and most importantly provided monetary compensation for interview/survey participants in the form of gift cards which helped to encourage participation from those deeply ensconced in their organizational programmatic activities.

This study operationalized for the first time, implementing the TRIRISK Model of Risk Perception to differentiate the tripartite perceptions of deliberative, affective, and experiential risk among a unique group of staff from various governmental and non-governmental organizations engaged in humanitarian response, regarding their personal health risks associated with international travel to disaster impacted regions. Co-PI Jesse C. Bliss, developed a novel model which combined the knowledge, attitudes, and practices (KAP) framework with the TRIRISK Model to create the TRIRISK-modified KAP framework to study responder knowledge, risk perceptions, health-behaviors and actual health outcomes among this important study population. Outcomes from this research allow international humanitarian response agencies and organizations to better understand how to prepare staff for deployment to disasters and the myriad of health threats that are frequently encountered in such response missions where local infrastructure and access to health care services have been greatly impacted due to the disaster.

A total of 62 participants were consented and enrolled in the study each of whom participated in the TRIRISK-modified KAP field interview questionnaire. Of those, 60 participants met inclusion criteria and completed the survey. 40% of respondents were female and 60% were male. Ages ranged from 25-63 with most participants in the 25-34 and 35-44 age brackets (28% and 35% respectively). 98% of participants had a 4-year college degree or higher (55% held masters or doctorate advanced degrees). Prevention and treatment knowledge average score was 77%, with the lowest score for knowledge of how to reduce risk of illness (69%).

The broader impacts of this RAPID DDRIG can offer insight into how to target specific knowledge, risk perceptions, and health behaviors among humanitarian response personnel so as to minimize negative health outcomes and support effective and strong mission focus and engagement in programmatic activities.

Post travel data entry, analyses, and project reporting were greatly impacted by the global COVID-19 pandemic which impacted both professional occupation related factors as well as personal impacts for the researchers involved in the project. Although lengthy delays ensued, the critical importance of this research and uncovering the insights from the data collected are essential to supporting effective and safe humanitarian response and helping to inform travel medicine providers how best they can help prepare their patients for deployment.

Public dissemination of this research is underway with the development of scholarly articles (2-3 papers) and professional presentations as public health and travel medicine conferences continue recovering from COVID impacts and delays. 3-5 national and global conference papers are expected to be accepted in the coming months helping to further disseminate the findings from this study.
